entry.title: Mass Actions in Statutory Reporting – Part 2: Scheduling for Timely Execution
entry.content:
Introduction 

In the previous blog, we explored how Mass Actions simplify statutory reporting by allowing users to perform a single action across multiple tasks. This feature reduces manual effort across tasks. 

Among the available options, Schedule Mass Action adds even more value by letting users automate actions to run at a specific time aligned with reporting deadlines. In this follow-up, we will dive into how scheduling ensures timely compliance in your reporting process. 

Let us take a closer look at how to set it up and make the most of it. 

Scheduling Mass Actions. 

Let us say we want to generate all monthly VAT reports on the 1st of every month, review them on the 2nd, and submit them by the 5th. We set this up once, and it runs like clockwork. 

Even when employees are away or simply overseeing the process, reports continue to generate and queue automatically in the background. The system knows. 

The scheduling process flow follows three targeted steps: 

1. Choose the required Job Template – 
Choose a job template and assign a clear job name for easy identification. It works on two scheduling modes: 

a.  Schedule reporting actions to recur on fixed calendar dates: Ideal for known deadlines (e.g., 1st of every month). 

b.  Schedule reporting action to recur per period based on different reporting deadlines: Perfect for fiscal cycles or quarterly returns. 

  

This dual-template approach exists to accommodate the different reporting rhythms and regulatory requirements faced by multinational organizations. 

2. Scheduling Options 
Define a start date/time, an optional end date, and a recurrence pattern (e.g., monthly, quarterly). 

3. Set the required parameters 
Specify essential details such as the reporting entity, report type, or period - tailored to your use case. 

Once scheduled, your reports run automatically. Users can focus on higher-value activities, knowing compliance processing happens reliably in the background. 

With Scheduling, we can now: 

  • Ensures Timely Submissions 

Schedules actions to run at the right time, helping meet reporting deadlines without manual effort. 

  • Reduces Manual Workload 

Eliminates the need to trigger actions manually, especially useful for recurring or large-volume reports. 

  • Improves Efficiency and Planning 

Allows users to plan by scheduling tasks in advance, reducing last-minute pressure. 

 

To summarize 

Scheduling in Mass Actions allows users to automate statutory reporting tasks based on specific timelines. Instead of executing actions like Generate, Submit, or Approve immediately, users can schedule them to run at a future date and time, often aligned with reporting deadlines. This is especially useful when managing recurring or time-sensitive reports across multiple entities or periods. 

Hope after reading this blog post it will provide some useful insights about the features – Mass Actions & Scheduling. Feel free to provide your feedback, suggestions, questions in comments below.

entry.title: Triggering onboarding notifications based on candidates’ input during the Onboarding ADC
entry.content:
Email services is one of the features used in SuccessFactors onboarding to trigger different

types of notifications to the external candidates and internal active users. SAP offers standard email triggers in onboarding which can be turned on/off based on the customers' requirements. In some cases, customers may want to trigger the notifications based on certain conditions as well.

The condition is triggering the notification to recruitment team when candidate opt in for health declaration during additional data collection step, which should be triggered only after candidate completes the Compliance form signature as it is last step of onboarding process by candidate. Onboarding supports this feature by setting up a filter business rule which validates what candidate has entered as an input during additional data collection step.

Customer pain point:

Customer had difficulty in identifying which onboarding candidate has opted in for a health declaration to make the necessary arrangements prior to their company joining date.

Prerequisites:

  • Access to Email Services
  • Access to Configure Business Rules

Configurations:

Create a Notification template with suitable content in (ONB) Compliance Document Flow Message Category.

In this case, the notification template is created from standard template à (ONB) Compliance Document Signature task completion Template 

 

Note: Email category can be selected according to the requirement at when or what step the notification should be triggered and the notification templates can be cloned from the existing standard notification templates, like it’s done in this scenario.

Create the Filter Email Template Scenario Business rule to trigger the notification only when Health declaration in Additional Data Collection step is selected as ‘Yes’ by the candidate.

Add the created business in the Filter Business Rules field.

Expected result:

When the candidate selects ‘Yes’ for health declaration questionnaire during additional data collection step. The notification will be triggered to the Recruitment team.

Health declaration notification trigger when candidate opts in for Health declaration.

entry.title: How I Began My SAP SuccessFactors Compensation Journey
entry.content:
In July 2024, I began my journey in SAP SuccessFactors Compensation. I started as a Trainee Analyst, going through the SAP Compensation Implementation Guide and testing functionalities in the demo system. Initially, I thought building a Compensation template was straightforward but real projects quickly proved that unexpected challenges are a part of everyday work.

Over time, I worked on multiple real-time support projects. Since these involved existing templates, most of my tasks focused on updating configurations based on new requirements. Even then, I faced several complex issues that forced me to think deeply and learn continuously. I’ve also been part of implementation projects where the problems required careful observation, functional clarity, and precise thinking.

I’m writing this blog to document my growth as a consultant. Starting this week, I’ll publish a new blog every Monday. I’ll share the problems I encounter, the solutions that work, and the lessons I learn both technical and functional. If there’s one thing experience has taught me, it’s that technical configuration matters, but functional understanding matters just as much, if not more.

I’ve gained a lot from the SAP Community, and now I feel it’s time to give back.

Special thanks to @xavierlegarrec for those insightful blogs and keeping the community updated.

SAP SuccessFactors Compensation

entry.title: SAP Business ByDesign FIFO management
entry.content:
Dear all SAP Business ByDesing Expert,

 

Currently, our company is looking to implement a ByDesign implementation project for a customer in Europe.

Our customer stated that the project would proceed only if FIFO cost management was perfectly implemented in ByDesign.

If any experts with experience implementing FIFO costing in European countries could offer some advice, it would be a great help in successfully completing our valuable project. I would truly appreciate your feedback.

If you have any advice for us, regardless of the question below, we would greatly appreciate it.

 

[Question]

We would like to request clarification regarding the FIFO Material Cost Accumulation logic in relation to Landed Cost processing in SAP Business ByDesign.

[Background]

In Purchase Order, we entered a Landed Cost Planned Amount of 10 USD. Subsequently, the Actual Supplier Invoice amount was 15 USD, and this Actual Amount was correctly allocated to the PO through the Landed Cost Allocation process.

In our expectation, when executing Material Cost Accumulation, the Actual Amount (15 USD) should be reflected in the FIFO layer, since the Actual Landed Cost has already been allocated to the relevant PO line. However, we observed the following behavior:

[Issue Observed]

  • *FIFO Layer Creation After running Material Cost Accumulation, the system still creates the FIFO layer based on the Planned Landed Cost (10 USD) instead of the Actual Amount.

    [Question]

    Could you please confirm whether the current system logic is designed such that:

    ➜ Even when inventory still exists for a PO with Landed Cost, the Actual Landed Cost Amount is not reflected in the FIFO layer during Material Cost Accumulation?

    In other words, is it the standard behavior of SAP Business ByDesign that: FIFO Layer is always created with Planned Landed Cost, and Actual Landed Cost Amount does not update or revalue the existing FIFO layer?

     

    [Expectation]

    From a costing perspective, we believe the Actual Landed Cost should be reflected in the FIFO layer to ensure: the remaining inventory value is updated accurately

     

    Thank you

    Best Regards

    JW

entry.title: Material Management - Release Strategy
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I would appreciate your advice regarding an issue related to the Purchase Order release strategy.

We recently had a requirement to perform a mass update on several Purchase Orders to set the “Delivery Complete” indicator, as all of these POs have been fully delivered and invoiced. During the mass update, I only selected three fields: Purchase Order, Line Item, and the Delivery Complete (ELIKZ) flag.

However, after the update, I noticed that this action unexpectedly triggered a new release strategy for the Purchase Orders. When reviewing the PO change log (see attached diagram), I can see that the release ID changed from A to B, even though no values, pricing, quantities, or line items were modified—only the “Delivery Complete” field in the Delivery tab was updated.

Based on the release strategy configuration shown in the diagram, do I need to adjust the “Chgable” (changeable) settings to prevent the release strategy from being re-triggered when updating statistical fields such as the “Delivery Complete” indicator?

Any guidance or best practices on how to handle this scenario would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you.

entry.title: Re: Cash Transfer - Batch
entry.content:
Hi @Albus 

I understand how you are using SAP Cash Transfer App (F0691) integrates with Bank Communication Management (BCM). The Cash Transfer App (F0691) is designed for single cash transfer transactions. Each transfer you initiate creates one payment request, and BCM then automatically generates a batch for that single payment. BCM itself can group multiple payments into one batch, but that depends on the source application. Since F0691 only produces one payment at a time, BCM receives only one item per batch.

To create batches with multiple payments, you would need to use an app that supports mass payment creation (e.g., Manage Automatic Payments or Payment Runs in Accounts Payable). Those apps generate multiple payments in one run, and BCM can then consolidate them into a single batch.

You cannot stop the batch process in F0691 to combine multiple payments. Yes, you can achieve multi-payment batches if you switch to a payment run–based app that feeds BCM with multiple items.
If your business case requires grouping transfers (e.g., several internal bank-to-bank transfers in one batch), you’d need to adjust the process design, Either use another app that supports multiple payments per run. Or configure BCM rules to group payments from different sources, but only if those sources deliver multiple payments in one go.

Hope you got the clarity

entry.title: Re: How To Set The PO Price Type Default Value
entry.content:
There is one app <Default Settings for Users -  Purchase Requisitions> in S4 public cloud system, which is meant for configuration expert using to assign default values for employees so that they don't need to enter the values manually.

Default PO Price Type is read-only in the employee view of the Default Settings for Users. Only professional purchasers can edit the field.

Please check the following steps in the system:

  1. To enable the Order Price Adopt. check box in the system.
    Go to App <Manage Your Solution>.
    Select Application Area as 'Sourcing and Procurement' and Sub Application Area as 'Operational Procurement'.
    Choose Item Name 'Requirements Processing'.
    Under Configuration Steps select 'Define Configurations based on Purchase Requisition Origin (SSCUI: 101965)' and click on Configure.
    Select the check box ‘Order Price Adoption’ for both Self Service Procurement and Professional Procurement.
    Then Save.
  2. Then ensure the following roles are assigned to the user:
    SAP_BR_BPC_EXPERT 
    SAP_BR_PURCHASER 

Once above 2 steps are done, the field will be editable to the user.

You can set the default value for users from “Do Not Adopt.” to “Net price.” as you wish.

For more information, please check KBA 3685401- PO Price Type Not Editable In Default Settings for Users App https://me.sap.com/notes/3685401

entry.title: Re: Question about tx ABAVN, ABAON, ABZON
entry.content:
Hi @RogerQB 
As per I know in SAP S/4HANA 2023, transactions like ABAVN, ABAON, and ABZON can post to multiple ledgers, but not selectively to only some ledgers (e.g., L4 and L5). By default, postings are controlled by ledger groups. You can configure a ledger group that includes only L4 and L5, and then post the asset transaction to that group. Without such configuration, postings will go to all ledgers simultaneously, and you cannot restrict them by movement type as in R/3

Ledger Group Concept in S/4HANA
Instead of valuation areas tied to movement types (as in R/3), S/4HANA uses ledger groups.
A ledger group can contain one or more ledgers (e.g., L4 and L5).
When posting an asset transaction, you can specify the ledger group so that the posting only affects those ledgers.

Transactions ABAVN, ABAON, ABZON
These transactions (retirement, transfer, acquisition without vendor) support ledger group postings.
If you select a ledger group containing L4 and L5, the posting will update only those two ledgers. If you don’t specify a ledger group, the system posts to all ledgers by default.

Difference from R/3
In R/3, you could restrict postings by movement type per valuation area. In S/4HANA, this restriction is no longer available. Instead, ledger groups replace valuation area logic for multi-ledger postings.

Practical Setup for Your Case
Define a ledger group that includes only L4 and L5. Train users to select this ledger group when posting asset transactions. This ensures that only L4 and L5 are updated, while other ledgers remain unaffected.

So the thing is you can post fixed asset transactions to multiple ledgers in S/4HANA, but only via ledger groups. To achieve your requirement (posting only to L4 and L5), you must configure a ledger group containing those two ledgers and use it during postings. Movement type restrictions by valuation area are no longer supported in S/4HANA.


Hope you will get help from my response. If so, please confirm

Hello,

Service team gets automatically derived during Service Order creation based on the country/region and postal code of the ship-to party or sold-to party. Service teams are automatically identified on the header of a service order, and are inherited by items.

entry.title: How to preserve remaining shelf life during post-processing batch creation in SAP?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I’m working on a project in FMCG spice manufacturing and need guidance on SAP shelf-life handling.

Problem:

  • Raw materials arrive with vendor MFG and EXP (SLED).

  • Materials may spend time in the warehouse before processing (e.g., grinding).

  • Currently, SAP sets the output batch expiry = Process Date + full shelf life, extending expiry incorrectly.

Goal:

  • Calculate output batch expiry as:
    Remaining_Life = Input_EXP minus Process_Date
    New_EXP = Process_Date plus Remaining_Life

  • Or, with fixed post-processing life:
    Candidate_EXP = Process_Date plus Fixed_PostProcess_Life
    New_EXP = the minimum of Input_EXP and Candidate_EXP

  • Earliest expiry should apply when multiple input batches are blended.

Questions:

  1. Is there a standard SAP method, BAdI, or user exit to implement this?

  2. Can it integrate with any already present logics in SAP?

Thanks for the help.

entry.title: Re: How to change the price condition which is overwritte...
entry.content:
Hi @floydausten.

You are talking here about Pricing Factors | SAP Help Portal.

That VC statement sets a factor for a given variant condition key.

The variant condition key is passed with the factor from the configurator to pricing.

Pricing uses the key to find the condition record of a variant condition (e.g. VA00 or a custom variant condition) and applies the factor when calculating the condition value. 

PR00 is not a variant condition but price condition. This is designed to be use to apply discounts or surcharges via variant conditions. 

Br,

Michael

entry.title: 销售订单号码段灵活编码
entry.content:
业务需求

使用可配置参数和公式（CPF）框架，作为配置专家的您可以定义新创建销售凭证号码段规则。这些规则能够实现销售凭证到编号范围区间的灵活分配，并可选择性地配置编号范围前缀。

配置总览

系统配置

1. SSCUI: 103283 Define Number Range Prefixes for Sales Documents

2. SSCUI: 102819 Define Number Ranges for Sales Documents

注意：自定义销售订单号码段不支持外部编码，欢迎有外部编码需求的客户提CIP.

3. SSCUI: 104014 Define Formulas for Flexible Sales Document Numbering

我这里用的案例是：公司代码1310+订单原因006（实惠价格）= 编码前缀CN+编码范围区间01

4. SSCUI：104015 Define Custom Routines for Flexible Sales Document Numbering

entry.title: Support of Working Day Calendar in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Background

A Working Day, also known as Business Day or Factory Day, is an official work day. And the working day calendar, if compared with standard calendar, it will exclude the weekends (Saturday and Sunday) together with national holidays.

In SAP Analytics Cloud, there will be some activities need to be scheduled in a recursive way, such as a daily work, a weekly or bi-weekly work. In the past, these activities can be planned using the standard calendar. But the standard calendar can not differentiate between a working day or a non-working day. As a consequence, some un-necessary tasks will be activated and lead to additional house-keeping effort.

Starting from QRC4 2025, working day calendar is now supported in SAP Analytics Cloud. User can now define recurrence settings using a working day calendar. Series based on working day calendars will have no occurrences on non-working days.

How to set up a working day calendar

Before use the working day calendar in the recurrence settings, a working day calendar needs to be defined in advance. Customers need to define their own working day calendars, since different regions may have their own working day calendars. This can be achieved by defining a Date dimension as User-Managed instead of System-Managed dimension. Because by defining a user-managed data dimension, user can add additional properties to that date dimension and use those properties to indicate whether it is a working day or non-working day.

User can create a new property like the below screenshot:

Please make sure the property ID is started with "CAL_WORKING_DAY_" so the system will recognize this property as working day calendar. And then maintain the property for each member. 1 for working days and 0 for non-working days.

 

Customers may ask, does that mean I should modify the Date dimension for all my existing models?

The answer is NO. The related recurrence setting will allow user to select a working day calendar from a different model. This means, user can create a model with working day calendar defined, and reuse that model in different scenarios and related models. Although custom can use an existing model and enhance the date dimension accordingly, but it could be more convenient to create a brand-new model, so the working calendar can be managed centrally without impact existing models. And there's another reason to define a brand-new model. Since reading the working day calendar information from the model will still follow the data access control as a standard model object. A brand-new model under public folder will avoid additional effort for authentication configuration.

For more details about how to set up a working day calendar in a model, please check the related help document:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/00f68c2e08b941f081002fd3691d86a7/785164b1c1234c5286882ff085e4d23d.html#how-to-set-up-a-working-day-calendar-in-a-model

 

How to use the working day calendar for your series

Currently, the working day calendar can be used in the recurrence setting, which is used in some features, including:

Calendar task, Schedule Publication, Data Change Insight.

Using Calendar task as an example, when create a task which needs to be recursive, the option to use working day calendar will be available.

As shown in the above screenshot, user can set the recurrence patten and select the desired days for working days. User will be able to choose the corresponding model and property created in advance.

If the recurrence pattern is set to week or month, the working day calendar is also available with similar behavior.

Besides the recurrent setting in task design, the working day calendar can also be used in the calendar list view.

In the Gantt Chart Settings, user can also enable showing the calendar with working day calendar.

Once this setting is turned on, the gantt chart display will display the non-working days in grey if there's at least one event loaded in the calendar.

For more details about how to set up recurrence using working day calendar, please check the below online document:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/00f68c2e08b941f081002fd3691d86a7/785164b1c1234c5286882ff085e4d23d.html#how-to-set-up-recurrence-using-a-working-day-calendar

The settings for Schedule Publication and Data Change Insight will be similar.

You may also check the below demo video as reference.

 

If the above video doesn't work, you may also check it via below link:

https://video.sap.com/media/t/1_byk63fen

 

Thanks a lot and let us know if you have any questions or comments.

best regards, Roy

entry.title: Joule 事务性能力解析：优化SAP S/4HANA Cloud开票流程
entry.content:
Joule在10月份的更新中，为SAP S/4HANA Cloud公有云版本的开票职员（Billing Clerk）处理日常开票任务带来了全新的事务性能力。这一创新将原本需要在多个应用间切换、手动输入数据的复杂流程，转化为集中高效的对话式操作，提升了处理效率。

自动化识别与快速处理：消除手动输入负担

对开票职员来说，日常处理单个开票凭证时，手动指定复杂的凭证编号既耗时又容易出错。

Joule通过以下方式简化了这一流程： Joule能够自动识别并填充来自目标开票凭证对象页面的凭证编号，用户无需在命令中手动指定。当用户进入需要处理的开票凭证页面后，只需启动Joule并发出简单指令即可。 这一自动识别功能支持用户快速执行关键任务：

  • 直接过账开票凭证：用户可以使用简短的请求，如“过账开票凭证”（Post billing document）或“过账凭证”（Post bd）。
  • 直接更改开票日期：用户可以通过对话请求更改日期，例如“更改开票日期至今天”（Change billing date to today）或指定具体日期，例如“更改开票日期至 2025 年 5 月 15 日”（Change billing date to May 15, 2025）。

高效解决过账问题：集中化诊断与修复

Joule的核心价值体现在对“卡住的”开票凭证的集成处理能力上，即那些因过账问题无法成功过账到财务会计系统的凭证。Joule提供了一套完整的解决方案：

  1. 查找与筛选问题凭证

用户可以指令Joule显示因过账问题无法过账的开票凭证。为获得最佳结果，建议用户始终从查找有问题的凭证开始操作。 用户可以通过指定详细的筛选条件来缩小搜索范围，例如：SD文档类别、开票凭证类型、问题类型、公司代码、销售组织或分销渠道等。

示例指令如：“显示问题类型为“会计访问”且开票凭证类型为 F2, CI01 的凭证”（Show billing documents with posting issue type Accounting Access, of billing document types F2, CI01）。

  1. 诊断与解决会计访问错误

Joule专注于解决当相关过账期间已关闭时发生的会计访问错误（如F5/286和F5/903错误），能够指导开票职员逐步解决这些错误。

  1. 修正日期并重新过账

如果诊断发现会计访问错误是由于开票凭证日期超出开放过账期间，用户可直接在Joule中执行修复：

  • 更改开票日期：用户可在聊天中要求设置新日期，或使用Joule提供的“Change Billing Date to Today”快速按钮。将开票日期更改为落入开放过账期间内的日期，即可有效解决会计访问错误 。
  • 重新过账：错误修复后，Joule会自动再次过账开票凭证。用户也可通过聊天命令或列表卡中的“Post”按钮手动过账。每次操作仅能过账单个凭证 。

请点击以下链接查看在Joule中简化billing功能的演示：

 Process Billing Documents with Posting Issues in Joule_SimpleVersion

 前提条件

要使用Joule的开票能力，在确保了Joule的开通和配置后，用户必须拥有分配了Sales - Billing Documents (SAP_SD_BC_BIL_DOC_PC) 业务目录的业务角色。默认情况下，Billing Clerk (SAP_BR_BILLING_CLERK) 业务角色模板已包含此业务目录。

请查看往期blog了解更多Joule的基础功能以及如何开通免费的BASE AI包开始使用Joule。

Joule功能全景介绍：Joule在SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition... - SAP Community

即刻免费解锁：SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 基础 AI 包 (B... - SAP Community

entry.title: Re: IAS User Mail
entry.content:
For both types of users account activation emails may be sent by IAS.
The question is whether this is desired for users from Azure(Entra): likely the authenticating IdP for these users is Entra and so it is not required run through account confirmation and setting of local credentials in IAS. However if desired it can be configured like this and 'On behalf'  will be the relevant email template.
For users registered in IAS it depends whether they register themselves or will be created by an admin. 'Self registration' or 'Invitation' and for users created by an admin 'On-behalf Registration' email template will be the relevant one.
Which mail server is used is a different question: if nothing is configured, IAS uses default mail server - see also https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/configure-mail-server-for-application-processes

entry.title: SAP BTP ABAP Environment – Maintenance Windows and Major Upgrade Windows in 2026
entry.content:
One of the benefits of using SAP BTP ABAP Environment is that updates and upgrades are applied by SAP to the systems in quite a high frequency and close to the corresponding release time.
Find the latest known schedule of Major Upgrade Windows and Weekly Maintenance Windows for 2026 in this blog post.

 

Major Upgrade Windows

As in 2025, the SAP BTP ABAP Environment will have 4 Major Upgrade Windows in 2026. These 24 hours of potential system unavailability are used to upgrade the systems to the next major version.
The events for the Major Upgrade Windows are harmonized between all SAP Cloud Products and scheduled for the following weekends:

  • February 14th – 15th (Release 2602)
  • May 16th – 17th (Release 2605)
  • August 15th – 16th (Release 2608)
  • November 14th – 15th (Release 2611)

Depending on the data center region, the 24 hours downtime will start/end at:

  • MENA: FRI 1 am - SAT 1 am UTC
  • APJ: FRI 9 pm – SAT 9 pm UTC
  • Europe: SAT 4 am – SUN 4 am UTC
  • Americas: SAT 10 am – SUN 10 am UTC

Please find the release schedule of the referenced UI5 versions in this blog post.

 

Weekly Maintenance Windows

Potentially every weekend, the SAP BTP ABAP Environment could use a downtime of 4 hours, to apply SAP HANA Cloud updates, Hotfix Collections and other changes.
Depending on the data center region, the 4 hours downtime may start at:

  • MENA: FRI 5 pm UTC
  • APJ: SAT 2 pm UTC
  • Europe: SAT 9 pm UTC
  • Americas: SUN 5 am UTC

The planned schedule for Hotfix Collection imports after upgrade to release 2602 will be published by end of December.

 

Reduction of Planned Maintenance Windows

We introduced Downtime-optimized Upgrades and Hotfix Collection Imports for Production with release 2502. For the next steps about the Reduction of Planned Maintenance Windows for HFC Imports and Upgrades see our roadmap.

 

Prepare for 2602: Cloud Foundry CLI and CAPI

Starting with release 2602, the service broker for the SAP BTP ABAP Environment will switch to asynchronous processing for service binding and service key creation requests. This change will impact client applications using interfaces like the CF CLI and CAPI. Refer to Service Key and Service Bindings Requests will change to asynchronous processing for more details.

 

Cloud System Notification Subscriptions (CSNS)

Please register to Cloud System Notification Subscriptions (CSNS) in SAP for Me to get important information about planned and unplanned downtimes:

  • Access to Cloud System Notification Subscriptions (CSNS): https://me.sap.com/systemsprovisioning/getNotified
  • Find more information about Cloud System Notification Subscriptions (CSNS) in this documentation
  • To find the SAP BTP ABAP Environment entry select:
    Cloud Service: SAP BTP ABAP environment
    Solution Area: SAP Build

 

References

  • Maintenance Windows and Major Upgrade Windows for SAP Cloud Services
  • SAP Note 2888562 – Intelligent Enterprise Suite: Harmonized release calendar for SAP Cloud products
  • Service Level Agreement for SAP Cloud Services

entry.title: What’s New in SAP Central Business Configuration 2509 FD1
entry.content:
With the latest release for SAP Central Business Configuration, an exciting new feature is available. This blog post will provide you with a concise overview.

Merging Business Configuration Enhancements Directly

For those familiar with SAP Central Business Configuration, the parallel line feature is a powerful tool. It allows you to make business configuration enhancements and test them in a secure environment without affecting your daily operations. Once you’ve made all changes in the parallel line, you perform the rebase operation to make sure any changes made in the main line in the meantime are included and that there are no conflicting values. Then, you merge your changes back to the main line and deploy them to your productive system.

Previously, the merge operation was initiated through a support case. To simplify and accelerate this process, you can now directly merge changes without needing to create a support case. This improvement not only saves time but also allows you to respond even faster to evolving business requirements.

Merge option in the Settings app

For a quick summary, check out this video about What's New in 2509 FD1. Don’t forget to also use the What’s New Viewer on the SAP Help Portal, which provides further details and links about all the recent changes.

That wraps up the new features this time. Did you like this blog? If so, please leave us a thumbs up at the top. Also, make sure to follow the SAP Central Business Configuration tag or follow this dedicated blog collection to stay up to date with the latest blog posts.

Do you have any ideas on how to further enhance SAP Central Business Configuration? Go to the Customer Influence platform to submit an improvement request or vote for the ideas of others. This helps us understand your requirements even better and prioritize our work accordingly. We’re looking forward to your improvement requests.

Kris

entry.title: Re: 999 – The Number of the BSEG
entry.content:
Hello Jack,

while the EV_POSTNG_CTRL field was first meant to only be used by the BAPI, we extended its use also to certain other dedicated processes called by the journal entry posting FIORI apps and the underlying ODATA services. So yes, the FIORI apps do not use the BAPIs, but this very FBDC_P060 tcode passes the EV_POSTNG_CTRL field to the ODATA service implementation (in header structure FDC_S_ACCDOC_HDR); the ODATA service implementation then calls the so-called accounting interface (functions AC_DOCUMENT_CREATE and AC_DOCUMENT_POST) and passes the EV_POSTNG_CTRL information in the header structure ACCHD. The ACCHD-EV_POSTNG_CTRL is then evaluated by the relevant BSEG summarization code (function group FACI, subroutine FI_DOCUMENT_COLLECT). Again: in this case, the summarization is not technically triggered by the BAdi, but by directly evaluating the EV_POSTNG_CTRL field. 

Please believe me, I implemented almost all of this myself 😉

Kind regards, 

Stefan

entry.title: Modern Enterprise Management with SAP: Key Capabilities, Use-Cases and AI-Enabled Integration
entry.content:
Modern Enterprise Management with SAP: Key Capabilities, Use-Cases and AI-Enabled Integration

1.   Introduction

Today’s companies face many pressures: complex global supply chains, changing staffing needs, customers who want instant service, and stricter rules and budgets. To handle this complexity, modern enterprise management systems (ERP) must do more than record transactions. They should provide real-time insights, connect processes from start to finish, and deliver smooth digital experiences for employees, customers, suppliers, and partners.

Different departments define “customer” in different ways. Depending on the team, the people they serve might be employees, partners, suppliers, finance teams, citizens, or shoppers. But they all have questions, problems, and requests that need to be resolved.

For many years, IT teams have used IT service management (ITSM) methods and tools to deliver and support IT services. Enterprise service management (ESM) takes these same service management ideas and applies them to other departments—like HR, customer service, finance, and procurement—to make their work simpler, more consistent, and more digital.

Key capabilities of an enterprise-management solution (SAP ESM)

Service catalog: A central list of every service each team offers, with clear descriptions and how to request them.

Service desk: One main help centre for questions, incidents, and requests, reachable by email, chat, SMS, or phone.

Self-service portal: An online place where people can find answers, submit requests, and track progress without calling support.

SLAs: Clear rules for how fast and how well services will be delivered, so expectations are set for everyone.

Automated, AI-enabled workflows: Automation and AI route requests to the right people and handle repeat tasks to speed things up and keep work consistent [1].

Knowledge base: A shared library of guides and solutions so people can quickly find what they need.

Reporting and analytics: Tools to measure performance, spot trends, and create reports for ongoing improvements and decisions.

Two example business scenarios-

HR: An employee requests leave or reports a workplace issue in the self-service portal. The request is automatically sent to the right HR staff, records are updated, and the employee gets notified when it’s done.

Finance/Customer–Vendor: A vendor submits an invoice through the portal. The system checks it, matches it to purchase orders, and routes it for approval. Finance can track status and fix issues quickly.

How integration across lines of business adds value :

SAP connects HR, finance, procurement, sales, and more so information flows smoothly across teams and systems.

Example: When HR approves leave or resolves a grievance, employee master data is updated automatically so payroll and scheduling stay correct.

This reduces errors, saves time, and ensures everyone is working with up-to-date information.

How built-in AI and automation enhance everything

  • AI and automation sort requests, send reminders, and analyze data to find trends, so routine work takes less time.
  • Teams can focus on higher-value tasks while the system keeps processes moving consistently.
  • AI can help predict issues and suggest fixes, making the organization more proactive and responsive.

In short, SAP ESM connects departments, streamlines work with automation and AI, and makes it easy for employees, customers, and partners to get what they need quickly

2. Business Scenarios: How it Works in Practice

Scenario A: HR / Workforce Flow – Leave Approval → Data Update → Grievance Management

Imagine an employee requests leave via a self-service portal. The manager approves via inbox, HR extracts insights, updates organizational and payroll master data, and subsequently a grievance arises (maybe a leave mix-up). Here’s how the platform supports:

  • Leave approval: In S/4HANA (or integrated HCM) the transactional app “Approve Leave Requests” enables managers to approve or reject leave requests for their direct reports.  
  • Core HR master-data update: The HR module supports recording of master employee data, organizational structure, time recording etc.  
  • Grievance / case-management: Through the Service Management (ESM) layer the employee’s case (e.g., grievance about leave calculation) can be logged, auto-classified, routed to the correct HR agent and resolved via knowledge-base/self-service. For example, the Help-Portal entry for ESM mentions automatic case creation, categorisation and routing.  
  • Integration: Because HR and the employee master data live in the same platform, updates triggered by the leave approval (for example, changed leave balance, change in cost centre or reporting line) can feed into downstream processes like payroll, time sheet, internal billing or cost-charging.
  • Insights & analytics: HR management gets dashboards showing leave utilisation trends, absence hotspots, grievance volumes by department; the same platform allows the HR team to monitor and act.
  • AI/automation: Using the HR-service solution, the AI copilot (for example Joule) can assist employees via chat or guided self-service for typical queries (“What is my available leave?”), auto-classify tickets (“leave balance grievance”) and assign to correct HR agent.  

 

Why this matters:

  • Employee experience improves: self-service, faster approvals, transparency.
  • HR efficiency increases: fewer manual tasks, faster resolution of cases, fewer errors in master data.
  • Master data integrity improves: because updates flow into a common model, downstream processes (payroll, cost-allocation) benefit.
  • Visibility and agility: HR leadership gains real-time visibility into workforce metrics.
  • Compliance & control: Processes are audited, controls can be embedded in workflows, data protection features included.

Scenario B: Customer / Vendor Financial Process – Customer Invoice Inquiry & Payment Advice Posting

Turning to the finance side and front-office/back-office interactions: Consider a vendor or customer calling the enterprise with an invoice status inquiry, or sending a payment advice which must be posted against the receivable ledger.

  • Accounts Receivable / Incoming invoice & payment: The capability-map shows that “Accounts Receivable” is part of Finance Operations in S/4HANA.  
  • Digital invoice processing: The blog on incoming-invoice-processing with S/4HANA describes scanning/email/EDI, automated data extraction (OCR/AI), workflow for approval, and posting once approved.  
  • Self-service & service-agent scenario: Under ESM, an agent desktop allows customer/supplier search, employee search, knowledge-base lookup and case routing for invoice or payment queries. The Feature-Scope for Enterprise Service Management lists entities like Customer, Supplier, Employee search in the agent desktop.  
  • Example use case: In the Leveraging ESM document, typical business user questions are “Why has my invoice been rejected?”, “Did you process the payment advice that I emailed you?”  

Process flow (customer invoice inquiry / payment advice):

  1. Customer calls or submits self-service ticket requesting invoice status.
  2. Service agent uses the ESM agent desktop: searches the business partner (customer), views open invoices, credit-holds, payment history (thanks to integration with FI/AR ledger).
  3. If payment advice is received (e.g., via email), it may be scanned or imported, matched to customer account, auto-classified, posted or flagged if mismatched.
  4. If an exception (e.g., invoice rejected, credit-limit exceeded) is found, the case is automatically routed to the correct finance team for resolution.
  5. Customer receives notification/status update via portal. The underlying AR ledger is updated and dashboards reflect DSO (days sales outstanding) metrics, open items, aging, etc.
  6. AI/automation: the system can suggest resolutions (e.g., suggest posting location, note to agent “invoice has been posted automatically after validation”), summarise case history, extract entity info from the payment advice document.

 

Why this matters:

  • Enhances customer / vendor experience via faster resolution and transparency.
  • Reduces finance servicing cost (less manual lookup, fewer escalations).
  • Improves working capital (faster cash-application, fewer outstanding items).
  • Provides analytics for finance leadership (clear view of receivables, credit-holds, aging trends).
  • Improves collaboration between front-office (service/call-centre) and back-office (finance ledger) because both operate in the same integrated platform.

3. Integration Across Lob’s – Making the “Enterprise” in Enterprise Management

The power of these platforms truly lies in integration: not just modules working separately, but data, workflows and services crossing boundaries.

Examples of integrated flows:

  • HR → Finance: When an employee changes cost-centre or department (via HR master-data update), this automatically triggers updates to financial cost-allocations or internal billing (if relevant).
  • HR → Service: An employee raises a grievance, the HR service-management module routes it, captures resolution, updates master-data or organisational info (e.g., manager changed).
  • Finance → Service/Customer: Invoices or payment issues raised by customers trigger service-cases; the service-agent has direct access to financial ledger data (via ESM agent desktop) and resolves faster.
  • Procurement/Payables → Finance: Vendor invoices (procure-to-pay) feed into the accounts-payable ledger and analytics on vendor-performance, cash-timing, discount capture.
  • Analytics/Insights: Because all data resides in one system (e.g., SAP HANA in S/4HANA), cross-domain reporting (HR + Finance + Procurement) is possible (for example, cost of workforce + overtime + cost centre budget + vendor spend).

Why integration matters:

  • Eliminates silos → faster information flow, fewer manual hand-offs.
  • Improves data accuracy (one source of truth) → better decision making.
  • Enables process automation across domains → lower cost, faster turnaround.
  • Enables better insights across functions → e.g., linking workforce absenteeism trends (HR) with customer satisfaction/service performance (Service) or cost impact (Finance).

4. Built-In AI and Automation – The “Next” in Next-Gen ERP

As enterprises evolve, simply digitising legacy processes isn’t enough – smart automation, AI-driven insights and prescriptive analytics become differentiators.

  • The HR service-management solution emphasises “AI-driven case management, auto-classification, case summarisation, emails, recommendations” via the AI copilot “Joule”.  
  • The invoice processing emphasises “automated document processing, machine-learning components , Business data extraction and validation , autoflow / posting automation.”  
  • For service-management features “automatic case creation, categorisation, prioritisation, and routing to the right agent.”  

Keyways AI & Automation add value:

  • Document-intake automation: invoices, payment advices, leave requests, grievance tickets – reduce manual effort and errors.
  • Self-service guidance: employees, customers or vendors get faster answers via chatbots, guided flows, intelligent suggestions.
  • Predictive analytics & alerts: e.g., an employee’s leave pattern may trigger a burnout risk alert; ageing receivables may suggest follow-up action.
  • Workflow automation: automatic routing, escalations, posting of transactions once validations pass, all leveraging pre-built rules + AI suggestion.
  • Agent enablement: service agents or HR/finance staff get summarised case history, recommended next steps, machine-suggested resolution or content references.
  • Continuous improvement: analytics on process bottlenecks, service resolution times, invoice-processing metrics feed into improvement loops.

5. Why Enterprises Should Care (And Some Practical Tips)

For enterprises (whether large domestic-players, MNC local units, or global captives), the above capabilities translate into concrete business value:

  • Dealing with highly dynamic work-forces, regulatory compliance (labour laws, tax, GST, data protection) means HR and Finance need modernisation.
  • Customers/venders expect digital interactions (portals, status updates, query resolution) – service management integrated with finance/back-office becomes differentiator.
  • Global operations (multi-currency, multi-entity) demand real-time consolidation, simplified data structure (HANA) and embedded analytics.
  • Cost pressures: automation (AI, workflows) helps reduce operational cost of servicing, approvals, invoice handling, grievances.
  • Insight‐driven decisions: linking workforce costs + customer service + vendor payments + supply-chain gives competitive edge.

Practical tips for implementation:

  • Start with end-to-end scenario definition rather than isolated modules: e.g., define your leave-to-pay flow, or your invoice-to-cash and query resolution flow.
  • Ensure master data integrity: business partner, employee, vendor/customer data needs to be clean.
  • Use pre-built services/workflows (Fiori apps, Flexible Workflow, Inbox, case-management templates) rather than custom build where possible.
  • Leverage the AI/automation capabilities early: for example document-processing for invoices; self-service for HR queries.
  • Integrate across LoBs: not just HR or Finance alone. For example, ensure HR updates (cost-centres, org-structure) feed into Finance, or ensure customer-query handling has ledger visibility to resolve faster.
  • Focus on process performance metrics: invoice-cycle time, DSO, case-first-response-time, employee self-service adoption, etc. Use the analytics platform built into the ERP to measure and improve.
  • Pay attention to change management: Employees, service-agents, managers must adapt to new self-service apps, mobile approvals, chatbots, new workflows.

Conclusion

In today’s digital economy, enterprise management is no longer about simply capturing transactions and running reports. It’s about connecting people, processes and data, enabling end-to-end flows across HR, Finance, Service, Procurement and Sales, and injecting intelligence and automation to accelerate and simplify operations.

Platforms like SAP S/4HANA, combined with enterprise-service-management layers, provide the breadth, depth and modern architecture to deliver these capabilities. From leave request to master-data update to grievance resolution, or from customer invoice query to payment advice posting to ledger update – the integrated, intelligent enterprise becomes possible.

For enterprises embracing these capabilities is not just IT-modernisation — it’s a business-transformation lever: faster service, lower cost, better insight, more agility. If your organisation is onto the next wave of digital readiness, this is your architecture.

entry.title: Error: Dropping tables is not supported (in artifact:“my.bookshop.Books”)
entry.content:
I am working on my first CAP application (apart from the tutorials ofcourse). I am using node.js and a Postgres hosted in SAP BTP. 

I stated with the template build, completed multiple rounds of built and testing, ran locally with CDS watch and the application worked as expected. However, when I am trying to deploy this into CF, the postgres deployer task fails with an error message as shown below.

[PollExecuteTaskStatusExecution] 3af87674-613b-43f9-9eac-41c209b72ae7 [2025-11-24T05:12:22.793155] Error: Dropping tables is not supported (in artifact:“my.bookshop.Books”) (STDERR, APP/TASK/deploy-to-postgresql)#

I am not using this table. This looks like from the bookshop tutorial. I have checked extensively and nowhere in the source code there is any reference to this table. 

I thought this has remained from the SAP provided CAP application template (which I used to) and that template did use the bookshop data models. So, I recreated my app in a separate Dev space, and this time without using the CAP project template in BAS. I manually added the schema.cds, cat-services.cds. Added the package.json and mta.yaml files from the first iteration (checked them again for any reference to my.bookshop.Books reference).

But, I am still getting the same error. 

Then I created a test app to check all the tables in the postgres db. Did not find any table of this name. There was a table my_bookshop_Books in public schema. I deleted this one (I know it does not match in name, at this point I am out of ideas). No luck, I am still getting the same error.

Anyone knows what the issue could be? Where should I check and remove any reference to the my.bookshop.Books table?

Attached is the log file from the cloud foundry deployment process.

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to set a different tolerance percentag...
entry.content:
Dear @Ahmed_Baiomy,

To clarify, it’s not possible to set tolerance at the package level within a strategy, this can only be configured at the plan level. As a result, when a call object associated with a package is completed, the deviation between the planned and actual completion dates is calculated at the plan level and therefore applies to all packages in that plan.

If tolerance needs to vary by package, the right approach is to split the strategy into multiple single-cycle plans and schedule each with the required tolerance. This will give you the control and accuracy you’re looking for.

Best regards,
Rohit
SAP EAM Dev,  SAP Cloud ERP

entry.title: Re: Output Parameters for Handling Unit Label Printing in...
entry.content:

Output Management for Handling Unit Management, Integration with Handling Unit Label in Logistics Operations, Extensibility for Output Forms for Handling Unit Labels, Enhancement of Output Table with BAdI

entry.title: Re: TM New Attribute to addition selection profile and us...
entry.content:
Hi Prince,

Thank you for sharing this information. I was working on a similar issue, and it helped me solve it. Please allow me to ask a few questions for better understanding:

  1. Why are you enhancing /SCMTMS/S_TOR_QUERY instead of enhancing /SCMTMS/S_TOR_Q_FU_STG_PLN directly? Since /SCMTMS/S_TOR_QUERY is included in different query structures, wouldn’t this enhancement affect structures you might not want to change?

  2. Regarding Step 4: You are using the business object FU. What is the reason for using FU here instead of /SCMTMS/BO?

  3. Regarding Step 5: There is a transaction /SCMTMS/QUERY_ENH that allows enhancing TM queries without coding enhancements. Did you choose the enhancement approach for a particular reason?

Thank you.
Best regards,
Alexander

entry.title: Re: SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
Excellent blog, Svetlana. Thank you.

It's important that the customers are aware of the fact that starting with SAP S/4HANA 2025, the Business Function for SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA  will be turned on by default, because that will have license implications for our customers, and we don't want them to have an unexpected surprise.

Although you mention it already in your blog, I want to emphasize again that a Compatibility Pack extension is also possible for customers who decide to go the SAP strategic route for HCM solutions and subscribe to SAP SuccessFactors HCM solutions. From a licensing cost perspective, this is certainly something to explore for customers, as the cost structure of SAP SuccessFactors may work out more favourably than expected when compared to SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA.

entry.title: Re: Special G/L Changes
entry.content:
Configuration Activity "Automatic Account Determination" allows you to define alternative reconciliation accounts for the special G/L transactions, however the special G/L indicators themselves cannot be customized via SSCUI configuration, they are all pre-defined by SAP. It is stated in the KBA referenced below:

2761212 - Create or Change Special G/L Indicator in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to set a different tolerance percentag...
entry.content:
Good day @Ahmed_Baiomy 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Maintenance Strategy, Maintenance Strategy/Maintenance Planning, Maintenance Package

In summary, the public cloud does not support per-package tolerances. Due to the clean-core principle, maintenance strategies support only one global tolerance in public cloud. You can meet your business need of different tolerance percentage, I recommend you split your single-entry strategy into multiple strategies or multiple maintenance plans.

As previously mentioned, the public cloud does not also allow you to use custom logic or BAdI to override tolerances.

Let me know if you have further question on the CDS views creation.

 

Best regards

Chris
